pros: Insightly has great company culture. The people are all fantastic, from the CEO to senior management and individual contributors.
cons: Normal start-up issues that are to be expected.

pros: I've been working at Insightly for a while on the sales team. It is a great place to progress your career, learn, have fun, and make some money while doing so. Management truly cares about each individuals' success and makes an effort to get to know everyone on a personal level. My team makes me excited to come to work every day. Promoting from within is a priority for management and the company as a whole.
cons: We hired too fast for a bit and as a result, hired some people we probably shouldn't have that were not invested in their own success and not a culture fit. These people are no longer with the company but are probably the cause of some of the bad reviews.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire the right people, continue to focus on promoting people internally and not changing the culture

review_title: It's been fun and it's been real.
years_at_company: It's been fun and it's been real.
pros:
The joy of working at Insightly stems from the people you meet. These relationships turn into friendship even after you leave their office for the day or move on to the next chapter of your career. It's a place where managers sit closely with their members and enable them to be successful. PeopleOperations (otherwise known as HR and Recruiting to the outside world) helped build Insightly, along with leadership's support and many team members' help, into a diverse, inclusive, fun, and engaging startup. It's one of a kind.

When you enter the office, you're greeted by the best Office Manager with her smile. You can grab a light breakfast, snacks, hot coffee/tea, drinks from the kitchen's pantry area. You will see each pod's unique style of decor like a hanging Lannister of Casterly Rock banner, a giant $1M sign, shady green leaves, a wall mounted bell that echoes loudly, and the quiet diligence of everyone striving to grow the business. Sometimes a furry Co-founder might say hi and search for food. Then lunch time hits and everyone is heading out to Barry's together, getting Lee's for the 3rd time in the same week, standing in line to warm up their food, and catching up on each other's lives. Afternoon rush ends and you return to work, 1:1, maybe a quick post-lunch ping pong game to stir up creativity, or your next meeting. It's closing time soon but some people are thinking of their evening plans to hang out after work.

It's a small 1 floor at Insightly and you're in for a treat if you aim to develop yourself, make an impact, and earn the respect of your peers. Come work at Insightly to learn a whole lot about CRM, the tech stack, a SaaS startup lifestyle, and build lifelong relationships (and friendships).
cons:
Granted that not all startups are perfect, they can come close. There is always room for growth. A while back, each department aimed to grow its size to scale operations so PeopleOps team staffed each department in a fast amount of time. Teamwork, camaraderie, and a dynamic strategy got us there. Suddenly, we hit a snag with what we aimed to do: scale.

When a startup expands, so should infrastructure, onboarding, ramp up time, and strategy. The people that have stuck around for the longest time can have insights, best practices, and experience so they can be the biggest resource. Uplevel the tenured people and show them how much you value their contribution to learning & development tools, new opportunities, and an exciting vision. New leadership needs to bring new energy to jumpstart the team rather than the feeling of shock. Then keep that energy going.

Nonetheless, Insightly shares the same growing pains as any other startup in a market that's saturated, competitive, and costly. After my initial months, I learned a lot through researching CRM, sharing knowledge, and asking questions about what I don't know in order to keep the edge at work. This is where a strong and continuous onboarding program comes in and needs the full support of leadership to execute. Here are some things we needed: an articulated company vision, domain expertise modules about SaaS CRM, catchy value propositions, and a robust mission statement are a few quintessential to show remind everyone why they come to work every day.
advice_to_mgmt:
Keep sharpening Insightly's edge every day. It's a great company with a head-turning story that outsiders are willing to hear and get behind.

Leaders, always invest in your people because they are your biggest ROI. Show them how you wanted to be treated when you were in their position. Onboarding is such a crucial step in the new hire or current employee's life cycle. A best practice is to make things better than the way it was founded.

pros: Amazing culture and promising process
cons: Start Up and general Growing Pains
advice_to_mgmt: Be more transparent

review_title: Look at the reviews trend nosedive
years_at_company: Look at the reviews trend nosedive
pros: Most of the people are nice. Massage biweekly. Lunch on Fridays. Individual contributors try to overcome the many obstacles. Lax work schedules. There is a potential to be a stellar product.
cons: Recent manager hires only have concern about themselves. Employees can't give 100% because management gets in the way. So why work hard? You DON'T want to work in CS- too much dishonesty, fakeness and rude treatment from the VP and her pets. Demeaning in every way.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't be evil. CEO needs to be reasonable and stop doing everything. He's so micromanaging that he probably writes some of these positive reviews too. :p Get your good leaders back!

pros: Overall, the company is profitable and the product is great for SMB. Nice office, good food, great work-life balance.
cons: Growing pains of a new Sales team being brought on. Board probably dictated numbers that they had to back into which led to a ridiculous over hiring spree. Overall, it's a good job though from a Sales perspective and a place where you can learn and grow.

pros: Smart coworkers, but rarely listened to. HQ located next to Mosconi. Massage Wednesday’s, soft drinks, snacks, and similar golden handcuff type perks.
cons:
It seemed like upper engineering management was fearful of losing their job therefor micromanaged (aka panic management by the staff) but didn’t know the subject matter.

Review process was prehistoric. It was said that you might get a raise every two years and it was CEO approved. Designation or spreading of power was virtually non existent, like almost everything had to go up the flag pole.
advice_to_mgmt: As former Apple CEO Steve Jobs famously said “it doesn't make sense to hire smart people and tell them what to do; we hire smart people so they can tell us what to do.” Especially in a growing market this mentality is more than a motivator for your employees, it's a key to success.

review_title: Great company with a good culture! Only takes a few bad apples to skew reviews!
years_at_company: Great company with a good culture! Only takes a few bad apples to skew reviews!
pros:
In all transparency, I do not work on the sales team. I have been working at Insightly for a while, and I like my team and the culture in the company. I read a few of the last reviews and it made me think since we hired so quickly, some of the people that left were just not the right fit for the company. In my time here, I felt that we hired better people when HR was more involved in the process and had more say. … 



Show More
cons: People leave, and write very negative reviews, especially if they are fired. Unfortunately, they can be misleading as you can say you are a "current employee" or anything you want. I don't want it to be hard to find good talent for my team because of a few bad apples. I think "HR" can only do so much. Seeing this in many companies prior, it is mostly the managers that need to be accountable.
advice_to_mgmt: If you come from a big company your values will be different. Help HR and the rest of the company show how Insightly actually shines. MOST OF ALL don't let rotten employees take away from the hard work that people do for the product that actually like their job, because I LOVE mine!

pros: Insightly has one of the best cultures you could imagine. It seemed like the teams have morale from sales to CS to engineering. The perks side of things are great, anyperk, stocked kitchen, great PTO, etc which is something that people of course love. The product has made some major improvements over time but of course always room for more. There is some room for growth but it's only recently been a little more transparent.
cons: The CS team has amazing feedback after talking to thousands of customers however this feedback is not really taken into consideration by the main product decision maker which happens to be the CEO. It feels like there isn't a sense for who the product is for so the company is pulling in multiple directions and not making substantial progress. Although it always seems like there is exciting features coming out, the launches are always lack luster and never as desirable. I saw some great plans by a former designer and those were easily dismissed unfortunately.
advice_to_mgmt: Your employees want to stick around and help make the product great but managers need to be role models/mentors, not micro managers and help the employee grow so they stay with the company.

review_title: A Truthful and Accurate Account of Sales Team
years_at_company: A Truthful and Accurate Account of Sales Team
pros: WOW! There are some wildly varied reviews here. It is quite clear that some have been written by HR and others have been by scorned sales reps. I am in fine standing with the company and will give a fair assessment of my experience thus far. Pros- My colleagues are similar in that they are high quality, talented and compassionate individuals. It is a pleasure working alongside them from a personal standpoint. HR has and is doing a great job of finding that cultural match. We also have the standard SF start up perks you would expect.
cons: The cons are pretty simple. The vast majority of the team are not even close to their quotas. This causes unrest on the sales floor, lowering the morale of the group. Mix in PIPs with no explanation to the team on how those are being decided and now we have any angry/confused team with low morale. Finally add in the fact that managers need to get to their team quotas, numbers are low, and so they are micromanaging EVERYTHING a rep does. So to recap, the sales floor currently is filled with angry/confused, micromanaged, low morale team members.
advice_to_mgmt: It is not too late. There are problems on every sales team. If you come up with reasonable and realistic solutions to get your teams to goal a vast majority of issues will go away. Be transparent. It doesn't help to just say "we will get this right", How? How are we going to right the ship? This is not the worst place in the Bay Area to work it is just currently in a very rough spot. It is fixable. Management is young in their careers and hopefully they can figure the problems out before another round of reps leave...not a ton of time left.

review_title: Would Not Recommend Joining Sales Team
years_at_company: Would Not Recommend Joining Sales Team
pros:
Great Benefits
Snacks
Great Location
Some Amazing People to work with
cons:
Unrealistic sales quotas
Poor Culture
No Transparency and lack of communication from management
Micromanagement at all levels
No clear expectations
No work/life balance - very difficult to take time off
advice_to_mgmt: Be more transparent and open with the sales team and be more proactive with communication.

review_title: Management And Culture Is False! Don't Come Here!
years_at_company: Management And Culture Is False! Don't Come Here!
pros: I'm not sure what to add here - Massages every other Wednesday?
cons: It seems a lot of Insightly reviews and what we've done on social media, is fake. I am a currently employee here, and within the last 2 weeks 4-5 sales reps including our most tenured sales manager has left the company. From the last few reviews saying the culture is great etc... is all a false, which starts with the interview process. They will tell you what it takes in attempt to attain "top talent" to work there. Everything is a lie and HR takes it as a joke! When you complain to HR for management violating policies (elsewhere it would be unacceptable), they take it lightly and nothing is done. Overall, don't come to Insightly, everything isn't true from the start. Go elsewhere and save your time. I'll be leaving soon too.
advice_to_mgmt: Get new management. Micromanage from the start, and the management team has absolutely no trust in their employees, let alone censor.

pros: Everyone that I have met and worked with here have been kind, helpful and down to earth. They also have a great kitchen, that is fully stocked at all times! We even get massages on Wednesdays.
cons: As of now, I there are no cons that come to mind
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing!

pros:
Insightly has a significant user (1.5M) and customer base (30K companies) in the $40B CRM mega market. The company is growing fast by completely scaling a sales team this year. It's exciting and the momentum is palpable.

We are expanding our market presence beyond small businesses to the mid market. Furthermore, we are shifting from a pure self-service business to a sales-assisted motion. This is a great learning opportunity, but also fraught with challenges and risks.
cons:
We are growing perhaps too quickly. Managing the internal processes, roles and responsibilities is critical to our success, and currently is too chaotic and ill defined.

We are taking too long to build the connective tissue needed to manage this growth.
advice_to_mgmt:
Focus on the following:

1) Better articulation of our go to market strategy

2) Greater definition and rigor around the product roadmap

3) Build the cultural and departmental processes needed to avoid silos

pros: The people make this company. Everyone is happy to show up every day and work as a team. We also have a wonderful snack selection and they keep the fridge stocked. Catered lunch on Friday and perfect downtown San Francisco location.
cons: Typical startup growing pains but not bad.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep listening to employees.

pros: Awesome company culture, people actually stay around during happy hours! Great work/life balance.
cons: CEO needs to trust his employee to do there job and delegate the day to day more.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the culture going! Company is growing very fast, management should try and be more transparent with whats going internally.

review_title: Love the product and the BEST culture I have seen in a LONG TIME!
years_at_company: Love the product and the BEST culture I have seen in a LONG TIME!
pros:
I love working here. I am really passionate about the SAAS space and I have always been an advocate of a good piece of software making strides to go leaps and beyond boundaries of all others!

The teams are all very passionate and excited from Engineering to Product, Sales, Marketing all the way to Customer Care. I once heard our Head of Recruiting and HR say, that "behind every great product there are passionate and smart people who love working together to make things happen, and that is who we hire!" I could not agree more as that is apparent starting from her team to everyone her team brings in and I interview.

My team can be quirky but every addition seems to have passion for the space and love the product! The passion is also very much driven by our CEO.
cons: Growing fast is never easy! Keeping the culture fun and interactive is always a challenge. Hard personalities and passion mixes into daily worklife, but that is just the nature of a job!
advice_to_mgmt: Practice what you preach. Don't lose the Insightly identity internally or externally as we go upstream.

pros: Free snacks and drinks, but everyone likes free food.
cons:
While Insightly does have a few pros, they have more cons. One of them being favoritism. The favoritism is so bad that managers don't even say goodbye to certain employees on their last day. Sorry, not everyone likes to go out and drink.

The second con being lack of career advancement. The company will lie and say they are looking at internal candidates first, but that's just a ruse to fake career growth. For certain departments, employees are treated like second-class citizens with no chance to grow their skills. Be careful what job you take with Insightly because you may have to wait 2-5 years before they even promote you.

In the end, it's not worth working here unless you want to be stuck in the same role forever.
advice_to_mgmt:
Treat long-term employees with better respect. Hire internally first because they know your product, business model, and customers.

Stop making long-term employees feel they need to quit to find career growth

review_title: Recent changes have shown that the executives don't care about employees
years_at_company: Recent changes have shown that the executives don't care about employees
pros: The people are great. You get free meals every Friday. Massages every other Wednesday.

review_title: Huge potential, fun environment, C-Level Management needs work
years_at_company: Huge potential, fun environment, C-Level Management needs work
pros:
This software, for the price point, knocks it out of the park and there is huge potential for the product. Clients are interesting because no one use case is the same.

You get to work with great fun people, have weekly massages, and can be hands on cross-functionally.
cons: Executive level management is poor across the company. Also career growth, while encouraged, is not realistic. It's used more as a ploy to get you to work harder while you are there.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on your teams and understand they are what will drive this business forward.

pros: Insightly has good teams and feels like a community. Product is good, could be great. Sales team is keeping the business growing.
cons: Product is stalled by a selfish CEO that treats the product like a personal hobby. Engineering is not getting enough resources. Product team is useless. QA has to have every bug approved by CEO? Seriously? Everyone just carries out orders because their talents are restricted from the top.
advice_to_mgmt: Get help to learn to manage and let people do their jobs to let your product grow. You are not a one man startup any more. Let yourself be challenged and educated by employees. You are wasting their talents.

pros: Insightly has a great setup for people that are motivated and want to contribute to a single or several aspects of the company. There are nice benefits within the office as well as outside of the office too. There are many start ups out there, but none that are as focused or dedicated as Insightly, but they still like to have fun!
cons: For all the pros, there is still work that needs to be done! Everyone works hard and is expected to pull their weight - a necessity for a startup!

review_title: Great place for ambitious people who want to learn
years_at_company: Great place for ambitious people who want to learn
pros:
-Insightly is a great place to work if you have a desire to "wear multiple hats," and/or do things outside of the scope of your typical job description.

-Management is typically supportive of new ideas and suggestions, and in most cases, will encourage you to tackle any opportunities you discover for improvement.

-Great work/ life balance.
cons:
Pay is on the lower end of what you can expect from a SF Bay Area firm and the benefits are less than you can expect from most star-ups (no 401K match, no bonuses)

The lack of process can sometimes be frustrating, for some.
advice_to_mgmt:
-Make sure that as we grow, you maintain the amount of transparency your provide today.
-Look into paying more and/or offering variable bonus structure to retain employees longer.

pros: Management deeply cares for individual wellness, growth and development.
cons: Lack of mobile strategy.Burning time in fixing what is not working with micro soft stack.
advice_to_mgmt: There is no shortcut to success, including mobile development.Take risks early and often.

pros: People enjoy coming to work here. Employees are usually positive in the office. Great live/work balance and flexibility. Newly remodeled office.
cons: Benefits are below average for a startup with this amount of success and funding. That said, they're really good! Could use more vacation time.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to workers, remain youthful and vigilant. Keep doing what you're doing. More perks! Great job on the high employee retention rate.

pros: Besides the company perks, Insightly has given me an excellent opportunity to take more tasks that continues to keep me challenged on a day-to-day basis. It's a great culture, you work with an amazing diverse set up employees, and it's a good way to continue your career growth. Looking forward to seeing Insightly grow!
cons: Not much. As long as you have good time management and take responsibility for your work.

pros: Great atmosphere, the team is amazing. Everyone works really well together and we get great rewards such as team events, weekly lunches, weekly happy hours, weekly massages and a Clipper Card for travel to and from work.
cons: The company is still building its culture, but so far it's great!

pros:
I think this is a great place to work for many reasons:
The company has great potential for growth
Smart people, as well as nice/respectful people.
Fun place to work/great culture - lots of improvements had been made/implemented
Good benefits and salary
cons: Growing company - inevitably will have growing pains
advice_to_mgmt: Communicate more about changes, progress, and road ahead. Clearly articulate long-term strategy

review_title: Disorganized management, company with a culture problem
years_at_company: Disorganized management, company with a culture problem
pros: Snacks and drinks. Good camaraderie within departments, and some fun personalities to work with.
cons: All of the drawbacks are in Engineering. If you're coming into one of the other areas, you'll probably be happy, at least until Engineering drags everything else down. Management in Engineering is clueless - no knowledge of technology, just knows buzzwords. Micromanaging, absolutely zero delegation, trust, respect, loyalty, or honesty. Employees literally disappear with no notice to the rest of the staff, regardless of if they have quit or been fired. The company has lost well over a dozen employees this year alone, and it's not over. Engineering has lost more people than it has retained. Development process is supposed to be agile, but the management within engineering doesn't follow it or understand it. Hiring standards are relaxed - company is no longer looking for excellence, just obedience. Run far and fast if you're a developer.
advice_to_mgmt: Look at the department where most of the people have left from, and you'll be forced to see where in the management structure your problem is. Hint - it's not CS, Sales, or Marketing. Call back the people that have left and ask them to identify the main person that drove their decision to leave; act on that answer. Look hard at Engineering management and decide if you want technical excellence or mediocrity - your employees are good; trust them.

review_title: Great product, high turnover, bad management
years_at_company: Great product, high turnover, bad management
pros: Friday Lunches (take-out), Thursday massages, snack bar (small for a startup, but you can request almost anything), good teammates. Customer Service is a focus of the company. It has all the right stuff for an amazing company, just needs management.
cons: Working from home is discouraged/disallowed. Extremely-high employee turnover. Several employees didn't even last a week, very few in Engineering/Operations will last a year. Unclear communication from management with conflicting priorities. You'll often get directions from two layers of management as if they don't talk to each other. Expect little positive feedback, no opportunities for advancement, no-notice weekend work, and to be replaced at any time. If you make it past 3 months, you might be ok. If you're promised something in an interview, get it in writing, and be prepared to negotiate for your salary. Non-engineering employees seem a little happier.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on productivity, not face-time in the office. Trust your employees. Communicate to the staff. Communicate within management. Provide for skills and career advancement.

review_title: Senior Management Needs to get Their Act Together
years_at_company: Senior Management Needs to get Their Act Together
pros: Incredibly talented, diverse, and energetic team. Lunch on Friday, massage on Thursday, snack bar and fridge stocked with drinks. Good product and some really great customers.
cons: Customer Service is the claimed focus of the company but it takes a moment for the management team to do anything when customers raise a fuss. Some senior management don't have a clue about what they are doing. There's no trust extended to the employees to do their jobs. If management thinks your work isn't good enough the feedback is anything but constructive. In fact, it's borderline abusive.
advice_to_mgmt: Get your act together. Trust your employees to do their jobs before we all leave.

pros: Small and fun start up. good company culture and transparency across teams! Very customer focus driven company.
cons: Bring back the happy hour fridays!.

pros: Insightly provides the fun environment and huge upside of a startup, with the salary, benefits and work/life balance you'd typically find in a bigger company.
cons: Insightly offers some good in-office perks (weekly chair massage, weekly team lunch, free snacks & drinks), but not as much as some other startups.

review_title: Some people on the team can make the culture suck
years_at_company: Some people on the team can make the culture suck
pros:
- everyone is friendly
- highly smart people
- fun Friday happy hour
- free 15-min massage on Thursday
- lots of snacks
- free lunches on Friday
- if you agree with everyone, you'll do great there
cons: - if your opinion is different than the opinion of your manager, forget about your brilliant ideas. They hire you for your impressive background and ability to solve complex problems but once you're there, you have to play the game by their rules. If you choose to speak up about that type of engagement or express a concern about a lack/dysfunctionality of a certain process, your manager might tell you it's all your fault, which will lead to further unpleasant issues.
advice_to_mgmt:
- invest more not only in company culture but also in team culture. That culture needs to come from team lead. If that person is only concerned about meeting a deadline but doesn't care whether his/her directs are happy or not, that team leader's behaviour will make employees search for better career opportunities.
- create a feedback mechanism that allows employees to share anonymous feedback on their manager. That feedback has to been seen by company leadership. If the submitted feedback is negative, it must be considered and not be used against the employee who submitted it.
- improve PTO policy so people don't have to show up when they're ill. Currently, they have to because if they don't, they'll lose a day off (for those of you who don't know, employees at Insightly get 3 weeks off per year which includes both vacation days and sick time off)
